clues: This city is home to a famous tower that sparkles every night.
Known as the 'City of Love' and a hub for fashion and art.
fun_fact: The Eiffel Tower was supposed to be dismantled after 20 years but was saved because it was useful for radio transmissions!
Paris has only one stop sign in the entire city—most intersections rely on priority-to-the-right rules.
trivia: This city is famous for its croissants and macarons. Bon appétit!
Paris was originally a Roman city called Lutetia.

clues: This city has the busiest pedestrian crossing in the world.
You can visit an entire district dedicated to anime, manga, and gaming.
fun_fact: Tokyo was originally a small fishing village called Edo before becoming the bustling capital it is today!
More than 14 million people live in Tokyo, making it one of the most populous cities in the world.
trivia: The city has over 160,000 restaurants, more than any other city in the world.
Tokyo's subway system is so efficient that train delays of just a few minutes come with formal apologies.

clues: Home to a green statue gifted by France in the 1800s.
Nicknamed 'The Big Apple' and known for its Broadway theaters.
fun_fact: The Statue of Liberty was originally a copper color before oxidizing to its iconic green patina.
Times Square was once called Longacre Square before being renamed in 1904.
trivia: New York City has 468 subway stations, making it one of the most complex transit systems in the world.
The Empire State Building has its own zip code: 10118.

clues: This city is home to a royal family and iconic red double-decker buses.
It boasts a famous clock tower called Big Ben (though the tower's actual name is the Elizabeth Tower).
fun_fact: The London Underground is the oldest subway system in the world, opening in 1863.
London is home to the world's first modern public transportation system, the omnibus, which started in 1829.
trivia: The British Museum in London houses over 8 million works of art.
London is one of the most-visited cities in the world, attracting over 19 million international visitors annually.

clues: This city has a famous wall that once divided it into East and West.
Known for its vibrant arts scene and historic sites.
fun_fact: The Berlin Wall was constructed overnight in 1961 and fell in 1989, symbolizing the end of the Cold War.
Berlin is home to the world's largest urban zoo, the Berlin Zoo, founded in 1844.
trivia: The Brandenburg Gate in Berlin was once a symbol of division and is now a symbol of reunification.
Berlin has more bridges than Venice, Italy!

clues: Known for its iconic Opera House and Harbour Bridge.
This city's beaches are famous worldwide, especially Bondi Beach.
fun_fact: The Sydney Opera House is one of the most recognizable buildings in the world, designed by Danish architect Jørn Utzon.
The Sydney Harbour Bridge is often called the 'Coathanger' because of its shape.
trivia: Sydney is Australia's largest city by population.
The first European settlement in Australia was established in Sydney in 1788.

clues: Known for its carnival, samba music, and the towering Christ the Redeemer statue.
The city's beaches, such as Copacabana and Ipanema, are world-famous.
fun_fact: Rio hosted the 2016 Summer Olympics, becoming the first South American city to do so.
The Christ the Redeemer statue stands 98 feet tall and overlooks the city from the top of Corcovado Mountain.
trivia: Rio's Carnival is one of the largest and most famous in the world.
The Sugarloaf Mountain in Rio offers panoramic views of the city and bay.

clues: Home to the Kremlin and the iconic Red Square.
Known for its onion-domed churches, including St. Basil's Cathedral.
fun_fact: The Moscow Metro is one of the busiest and most beautiful subway systems in the world, featuring grand architecture.
Moscow's Red Square was originally used for military parades and public gatherings.
trivia: Moscow is the largest city in Russia, with a population of over 12 million people.
The Moscow Kremlin is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and one of the oldest fortified cities in the world.

clues: This city was once the heart of a vast empire that ruled much of Europe.
It is home to the Colosseum, the Roman Forum, and the Vatican City.
fun_fact: The Colosseum could hold up to 50,000 spectators and hosted gladiator contests and public spectacles.
Rome's famous fountains are a reminder of its ancient aqueduct system, which still feeds many of them today.
trivia: The Vatican City, an independent state, is located entirely within Rome.
Rome has more fountains than any other city in the world, over 280!

clues: Famous for its surreal architecture by Antoni Gaudí, including the Sagrada Familia.
It's also known for its beaches and vibrant arts and culture scene.
fun_fact: The Sagrada Familia basilica, which began construction in 1882, is still unfinished to this day.
Barcelona was once the host city for the 1992 Summer Olympics, which helped modernize the city's infrastructure.
trivia: Barcelona is home to one of the most popular soccer clubs in the world, FC Barcelona.
The city's Park Güell was originally intended to be a residential development but is now a UNESCO World Heritage site.

clues: Known as 'The City of Angels' and home to the Hollywood film industry.
The city is famous for its beaches, including Venice Beach and Santa Monica.
fun_fact: Los Angeles is the birthplace of the modern movie industry, with Hollywood being the center of global cinema.
The Hollywood Sign originally read 'Hollywoodland' and was an advertisement for a real estate development.
trivia: Los Angeles is the second-largest city in the United States by population.
The city is home to more than 1,000 museums, galleries, and theaters.

clues: This city is home to the ancient pyramids and the Sphinx.
Known for its rich history dating back to the Pharaonic era.
fun_fact: The Great Pyramid of Giza is the only surviving Wonder of the Ancient World.
Cairo is one of the largest cities in Africa, with a population exceeding 9 million.
trivia: Cairo is known for its bustling markets, such as Khan El Khalili, one of the oldest bazaars in the world.
The Egyptian Museum in Cairo houses the world's largest collection of ancient Egyptian artifacts.

clues: Famous for its vibrant street life, cultural landmarks, and ornate temples.
Home to the Grand Palace and the Emerald Buddha.
fun_fact: Bangkok's full name is the longest city name in the world, with 169 letters in Thai.
The city's Chao Phraya River is a major waterway running through the heart of Bangkok.
trivia: Bangkok is known for its floating markets, such as the Damnoen Saduak Market.
It has one of the largest and busiest street markets in the world, Chatuchak Weekend Market.
